title: Simple^2 Anti-Tension Customizable Spool Holder for Printrbot Simple Metal 1403
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Using other z-rod-mounted filament spool holders, I found that they caused undue tension on the filament when using fast retraction. The ones that tried to resolve this relied either on metal bearings, or overly complex (and large) solutions. Not finding a suitable one that I liked, I designed my own in OpenSCAD. The design allows the filament guide arm to flex on resume from fast retract, instead of having the full tension of the retract have to spin the mass of the entire spool. In testing, it works really well, and also minimizes overall filament tension by pulling from the spool more orthogonal to the spin moment and normal force. There are a few other touches like inverted cone over z-rod to allow it to pivot more smoothly, but still kept as simple and minimal design as possible. Demo of retract flex:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JVb58lKCKzM

I sliced in Cura with 4 shells and 6.8% infill (tweaked in Cura in layers view to get single-truss internal supports). If you want to print a smaller arm to fit spools like Taulman's, etc, it's probably best to download the scad source and compile in OpenSCAD rather than using Customizer. There are comments in the SCAD file with more explainations. I recommend using the printOnlyZrodBearing parameter to print just the z-rod bearing surface to calibrate the tightness before printing the entire thing. The 45-degree arm offset at the end is almost an overhang torture test. You may want to print a large 150mm tall cylinder next to it in order to increase cooling time of the arm. I also suggest printing without the guideHole, and driling it afterward, but have at it if you like a challenge ! :) Good luck ! Timelapse of print:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mncNZO2ifYY

Offloading Neuromechanical Interface Control to Multiplexed Prosthetic Devices using Interactive RFID Enabled Micro-controllers Offloading Neuromechanical Control to Multiplexed Prosthetic Devices using Interactive RFID enabled, Embedded Microcontrollers for both Complex object Manipulation and Globally Assistive Applications
For the most part prosthetic devices use non computer enabled mechanical components. The most advanced prototype systems, currently under development, seek to create neuro-mechanical interfaces. These approaches rely on the concept of primary "human control". However, many complex movements are in fact unconscious or “Zombie” programs running in different parts of the brain. In other words, we don’t have to think about them. This project enables the "environment" to allow a prosthetic device to control itself, thereby “off loading” enormous amounts of neural control processing while permitting the device to autonomously perform complex movements and tasks.
This experiment multiplexes an RFID sensor and servo actuators within a 3-D printed prosthetic hand. This approach places an RFID antenna in the palm of a 3-D printed prosthetic hand, connecting it to an embedded Arduino-Uno. This allows the prosthetic device to read different RFID tags on objects in the environment. Each tag may be associated with a different set of functions which would determine the movement of individual servo motors. This could give the prosthetic device the ability to execute different complex movements depending on which RFID tag is read by the antenna.
It may be possible to include a broad range of sensors within the 3-D printed prosthetic hand to expand innate human capabilities. This might even include data loggers to "remember" the life experience of the prosthetic device and a broad range of unique sensors. Background
The field of prosthetics has experienced major advances over the centuries. Unfortunately many of these advances have been associated with human conflict (for example, injured war fighters). For the most part, “smart” prosthetic devices have only recently become available, however they are often very expensive and rarely are they “customized” to an individual’s preferences or needs. Fortunately, the development of truly affordable embedded electronics, inexpensive 3-D scanning software and low cost 3-D printing platforms (in an open access environment) has revealed shocking new possibilities at an unprecedented pace of development and practical application. Experimental Design
Step 1: Configure Arduino UNO to read an RFID tag
Step 2: Configure Arduino UNO to control a 9g mini servo motor
Step 3: Write Arduino sketch to move servo after reading RFID tag
Step 4: Modify sketch to move different servos with different tags
Step 5: Design and 3D print prototype fingers with servo mounts
Step 6: Revise design to use springs as joints
Step 7: Combine servos, RFID Antenna, 3D printed parts and Arduino. Guino
“Guino” is a free Arduino Dashboard that allows a user to send information from the Arduino board, over the serial port and view this information on a host computer. This program shows the current position of each servo motor, the unique tag number identified by the RFID antenna and the action (“function” in the arduino sketch) that is linked to that tag. This dashboard need not be connected to the prosthetic, but allows a convenient means of illustrating the microcontroller actions. Results
Each of three tags was brought close to the RFID Antenna, 100 times. The number of times that the system correctly identified the tag number and correctly executed the appropriate function were recorded in tabular form. For these 300 separate tests, there were zero incorrect tag identifications and 100% success in executing the appropriate function in the Arduino sketch (embedded microcontroller). For this series of tests, the antenna, microcontroller and servo motors performed reliably. The finger design is unique to this project. The mechanical properties of the “spring” joints can be changed by using different springs, varying the length of the springs between the segments or by using more than one spring in the joint. Conclusion
This project has demonstrated that it is possible to offload neuromechanical control for complex movements to an RFID enabled prosthetic device. An embedded microcontroller correctly identifies several unique RFID tags.
Each RFID tag, when identified by the embedded microcontroller, is able to trigger a specific function in the Arduino script which in turn controls the movement of 5 separate servo motors in the prostatic hand. This project demonstrates that complex movements corresponding to tasks such as “grasp”, “pinch”, and “count” are easily and reliably achievable.
Embedding “Capsule RFID tags” in the tips of each prosthetic finger, would allow an interactive work station to identify at least 5 different, unique, RFID signals and respond accordingly to the presence of the prosthetic device.
This project has used the free “Guino” serial report monitor to display the interactive data stream between the RFID antenna, various types of RFID tags, the embedded microcontroller, and the Servo motors.
Summary: This project demonstrates a potentially useful approach to offloading neuromechanical interface control for both complex object manipulation and globally assistive prosthetic applications. Future Applied Research and Development
Temperature and Hall effect sensor (magnetic fields)
Individual human scanned and 3D printed prosthetics
2-3 axis tilt sensor for release and pick up
2-3 axis accelerometer for speed and direction
Capacitive Touch sensor for direct computer interface
Infra Red (IR) proximity sensor
Position sensing servos, “inverse kinetic” training
RFID Capsules in finger tips for workstation interactions
Wi-Fi prosthetic to prosthetic and remote between people
Smart phone “App” reprogramming and QR code reader
NFC Near Field Communication between limbs (walking) This high school science project was overseen by:
Dr. R. Siderits at RWJUHH Awards
  • The United States Air Force: Certificate of Achievement for an Outstanding Science and Engineering Fair Project
  • Intel Excellence in Computer Science Award: for outstanding achievement in the category of Computer Science at the Mercer Science and Engineering Fair
  • The Yale Science and Engineering Association Inc. Award: for Most Outstanding Exhibit in Computer Science, Engineering, Physics, or Chemistry
  • The Rider University Award: for the Most Superior Project
  • First Place award in the Computational Biology and Bioinformatics of the 2015 Mercer Science and Engineering Fair
  • Grand Prize of the 2015 Mercer Science and Engineering Fair

description.text: This is a vibration isolation mount for the KK2 family of quadcopter controllers (should fit any of the KK2 controllers.  Shown in pics is the KK2.0).  Mount will attach to the top plate of the Q450 quadcopter using existing fastener holes and screws.  Could be used on other quadcopters, but you will need to figure an alternate method of attachment.  You will also need to purchase the vibration dampening balls (go to hobbyking, and search for 'vibration 65g').  Design was inspired from vibration isolation mounts that I saw on this site from Guy McCaldin.

Designed to be printed without supports.  Holes in top mount plate (where KK controller mounts) are purposefully undersized, so that you can drill and use a screw which will thread directly into the plastic.

comments.text: What are the dimensions of the vibration balls? If they're the same size, you can also print your own mold and cast the silicone isolators yourself. http://repables.com/r/431/

comments.text: Great design!  More compact, and more efficient in its use of materials than the one I put out.

This is a vibration isolation mount for the Mobius camera.  You will need to purchase the vibration dampening balls (go to hobbyking, and search for 'vibration 65g').  Designed to screw under the bottom plate of a Q450 quadcopter, but is universal enough to be used just about anywhere.  Will work right-side-up or up-side-down.  Camera can be glued or taped onto top plate, or can be screwed into the 1/4-20 threaded camera mount (photos show screwed attached camera).  My experience is that this method of vibration isolation works exceptionally well.  Vibration isolation design was inspired from other designs that I saw on this site from Guy McCaldin.
Designed to be printed without supports. Eight mount holes are purposefully small so that you can enlarge them to whatever size you need.

title: Bluetooth XYZ Printing da VInci Cartridge Resetter

description.text: This is the housing for our Bluetooth version of our resetter. Unlike our USB version, this houses the electronics which are then placed inside an empty cartridge with just a small removal of some of the plastic in the cartridge. This ensures the USB module makes a good reliable contact with the printer so your prints don't quite due to the unit shaking loose from the contacts in the middle of a print. Like the USB version, the electronics or complete assembly are available at dimensionbx.com.
Print with 'Good' settings on any da Vinci 3D Printer.

comments.text: I few people had trouble with the full housing, it requires that the all the plastic be cleared behind the chip to make room so we stopped using it. The chip is held securely in place by the cartridge slots the same way for both designs, the full housing doesn't add any additional mounting security. Once the resetter is installed in the cartridge it need not ever be opened again so the wires will be protected.

author: dimensionbx

description.text: It is common to use strips of LED's to attach to the arms of a Quadcopter to be able to fly at night, or to help with orientation during the day.  LED's come in adhesive strips which can be wrapped around the quadcopter arms.  Unfortunately, the arms don't really make a great surface to attach to.  So I created these 3d printed strips which wrap around the Q450 quadcopter arms and provide a nice flat surface to adhere your LED strips to.  Search Hobbyking for 'LED Flexible' for a variety of available LED strips.

Parts are not symmetric - they are designed to fit the arm one way.  If you put them upsidedown, they will not fit as well.  I simply glued these strips to the quadcopter arms, and then stuck the LED strips to them.

title: Mini Kossel 2020 Stands and Smoothieboard Mount

description.text:
I wanted to mount the Smoothieboard below my mini Kossel. for this reason i added 3 stands to get the printer base a little bit higher.  
The Smoothie Board mount is modified for usage with M3 screws and nuts, which makes the whole thing very stable. I printed my parts in ABS, so i had no problems with mechanical strength.  
The 4 holders attach the mount to the stands.   
This things only fits the mini kossel with 2020 profiles.  
30.04.2015 Added Design Spark Mechanical design files

comments.text:
Thanks for this. Have recently printed and fitted on my Anycubic Kossel.
My only suggestion for improvement would be to decrease the length needed for the horizontal bolts holding the board mount to the brackets. I only have up to 18mm M3 bolts which are not long enough to get through. I suggest the width of the board mount could be reduced at least where the screws are to resolve this. I have used small zip ties as a temporary fix.
Aside from that, great.

description.text: A simple, 4 piece trebuchet.  All the pieces are sized to it on a 5th generation Replicator.  They may or may not fit on the build plate simultaneously, as I have not tried.  The weight bucket may be a little small, but otherwise this should work fine.

Print out one of each part.  The bucket may be difficult to attach, but everything else should pop on easily.  The arm should be loose, as well as the secondary arm and weight, though you will need to press the two arms together.  Load up the bucket with something heavy, load the arm with something light, pull back the arm and let it fly!

This one is printed as four flat parts and then snapped together.
You can use CA glue or acetone slurry or plain acetone to glue it if you want. I have also included my original design which I could not get to print without warping or delaminating. It has extra pads which can be cut off and you should use a brim. If you can get it to print properly, great. I couldn't and settled for the four piece design which is lighter. I did not orient all the parts for printing as I normally do. If you do not know how and need the bottom and sides rotated for printing, leave a comment here. The assembly is not intended for printing so don't waste your time downloading it. The left and right sides are actually the same part (flipped).

title: Cover for a solderless 9 pin D-Sub connector

description.text:
Cover for a solderless 9 pin D-Sub connector. (see photos)
Prints in two halves, no support required. Finding the right size screw to mechanically join the two halves may be tricky!
At the present time, unless the connector your fitting the assembled unit to has it's own connecting screws, there's no way to screw the D-Sub connector into it's counterpart as there's no access to the screw holes from the rear, so in this case it's push fit only.
Designed to allow access to the crimping screws and the wiring holes without having to unscrew the two halves.

A 3d-printed handle that contains a catch mechanism for homemade toy guns and can be attached to PVC pipe.  Also called the "Purple Catch".

Multiple handle files are provided. The main difference in them is the curve at the top, which determines what size tube fits best. BP3-4xx files are from the BullPAC 3, and fit 3/4" PVC.
PP-Handle and PP-Catch parts are an alternative version for 1 1/4" PVC. Both assume the catchplate needs to travel up to the center of the tube they are fastened to, and work best with a notch cut into 1/2" round delrin or nylon rod. Holes are all pilots for #6-32 threaded screws. They will probably need to be drilled and tapped, but you might get away with just drilling and screwing. The trigger is 2 mirror pieces that must be superglued together. The trigger and catch must be smoothed with a file or similar methods, but the handle shouldn't need smoothing. The handle requires a printer with at least 140mm of vertical travel for the handle, and very strong interlayer adhesion. Other orientations would be stronger, but can't get good enough internal features.

title: ULTIMATE Drawer Divider Collection - Fits Most Drawers, Modeled for Akro-Mils

description.text:
The ultimate collection of drawer dividers for both small and large drawers. Specifically modeled for Akro-Mils drawer but will fit most other drawers (or can be made modified to fit any drawer) Confirmed to Fit Akro-Mils 10716, 10726, 10744, 10764, 10116, 10126, 10144, 10164 cabinet drawers. It is strongly recommended that you print with a layer height of 0.27mm and that you print the drawers with supports and then cut the supports off once the print has completed (they are very easy to remove). I've included a 3ds Max file that contains all drawer divider types for easy modification (history stacks included). I've also included zip folders that contain the following:
  • ALL.zip: _____All drawer dividers (with and without supports).
  • ALL_PlusMaxFile.zip: _____All drawer dividers plus max file (with and without supports).
  • AllLarge.zip: _____All large drawer dividers (short and tall with and without supports).
  • AllLg_Short.zip: _____All large drawer dividers (with and without supports).
  • AllLg_ShortNoSupports.zip: _____All large short drawer dividers with no supports.
  • AllLg_ShortSupports.zip: _____All large short drawer dividers with supports.
  • AllLg_Tall.zip: _____All large tall drawer dividers (with and without supports).
  • AllLg_TallNoSupports.zip: _____All large tall drawer dividers with no supports.
  • AllLg_TallSupports.zip: _____All large tall drawer dividers with supports.
  • AllSmall.zip: _____All small drawer dividers (with and without supports).
  • AllSml_NoSupports.zip: _____All small drawer dividers with no supports.
  • AllSml_Supports.zip: _____All small drawer dividers with supports.

It is strongly recommended that you print with a layer height of 0.27mm and that you print the drawers with supports and then cut the supports off once the print has completed (they are very easy to remove).   
Infill: 20% seems to work fine for me but I do have a fan attached to my extruder that cools the plastic as it comes out. So you may just have to determine that based on what percentage in-fill works best for your printer.  
On mine, I just used 1 layer (wall thickness) - got better results.   
I printed all of mine in PLA and it worked perfectly. I'm sure it would work perfectly in ABS as well if that's what you normally print in.

This polyhedron is a genus 1 torus.  The name describes where it came from.  The faces are equilateral triangles, squares and regular pentagons.

I really like the basic Spider design from RCTimer, but the legs are just too short.  The extended legs RCTimer sells are too flimsy, and causes the quad to bounce around when landing. These extended landing gear slip over the existing legs and attach with one bolt.  These were printed in ABS with 20% infill. I am using a 3mm x 16mm cap screw with two washers and a lock nut.  Simply drill a hole through the divit that is already on the existing leg. Slide the extended gear on and secure with the 3mm bolt.  
These legs may work with other Spider quadcopters but they were designed specifically around the legs from RCTimer.

A printable, single-piece Forget-Me-Not flower. The overhang of the pillars is 45 degrees, so most printers should be able to print it. The scale on the .STL file is not precise so you will have to tweak it on your own, but I will update the file when I have time. "The Forget Me Not flower is the official emblem of the worldwide
observance of the centennial year of the Armenian Genocide. It expresses the theme of eternal remembrance, and is also
meant to symbolically evoke the past, present, and future experiences
of the Armenian people."
You may learn more it about it here: http://www.armenianchurch-ed.net/uploaded_files/tinymce/files/pdf/GenocideEmblemExplanationFlyer.pdf. and here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PrrjTuKuXZE

I needed to adjust headlights on my Ford Crown Victoria after installing HID lights, but found that it is almost impossible to get there with a socket wrench. There is even special tool for it, but it costs $20 and you have to wait a week for delivery...  
This tool gets on the adjustment bolt and allow you to use your bare hands to tighten it. Takes just seconds to adjust it, once you are done printing.  
I read that many other cars use same size of the hex bolt, but different cars might have different clearances. Attached is Freecad source file you can modify anytime to fit your particular car.  
PS: holes on the side were initially put by me to allow using something to spin it if bolt get stuck, but it turned out using just hands is enough.
You probably want to use a bit more perimeters to make sure bolt will not damage plastic. I did 4 perimeters and it hold up very well.

title: Dual 60mm fan side mount for the XYZ Da Vinci printer

description.text: A remix of the excellent thing:731176 with a redesigned fan grid that improves the airflow and support for installing a potentiometer on the inside to control the RPMs. I also tweaked a bit the side tabs that hold it in place. This kind of side cooling can be really helpful with all PLA prints, and even with ABS, if used carefully. I can now do crazy overhangs like these easily.

When printed in ABS it tends to warp a lot, specially on the ends, so be sure to use whatever you have to use in order to improve bed adhesion (I find that the so called 'ABS juice' works best).  
I wired the 2 x 60mm 12v fans directly to the printer's 12v input on the control board in the back. They only use roughly 0.22A combined, so there is really no need for an external power source.  
Optionally you may also install a potentiometer in order to be able to manually control the speed of the fans. These 2 little beasts really blow a lot with the improved fan grid design, so being able to tune them down a little comes very handy for some sensible prints. The potentiometer I used is a standard 10K-Ohm (I believe) and measures 16x16x7 mm.

title: OpenSCAD Awesome 3D Rectangular Prism Curved Edge Generator

description.text: This is an awesome code I wrote, that very easily, by simply edit a few variables lets you create any size cube/prism you want, and lets you change the roundness of the edges of the prism to almost anything you want. Feel free to copy and paste and implement this into any of your code, and use it how ever you want. I find this code very useful for simple object design. View the 2D of this at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:780039 .

When you open this code in your version of OpenSCAD, (if you do not have it, I highly recommend it!) at the top of the code, you will see 4 int variables you can edit, to change the size and roundness of the prism. Width, edits the width of the prism (in mm). The same for length, and height. cornerps, edits the roundness of the corners of the prism. Feel free to mess around with it, and do what you want with it! Make it better! For questions, and links to your creations please email me at [email protected] .

author: Rhysma

title: Customizable filament/wire spool or wheel creator

description.text:
This is a customizable filament spool or wheel creator.  I created this to make a filament spool for some loose filaments I have but by turning off filament holes it can create wheels as well.  The hub and outer diameter are adjustable as well as a few other options.  This spool/wheel creator uses an angled fillet which allows the upper ring to be printed without supports.  
I may modify this to add more options in the future.  This is a project to help me learn the OpenSCAD programming language.  
The stl included is my version of a filament spool for loose filament and was printed on a FlashForge Creator Pro, the hub is designed to fit a Hatchbox spool holder.  
Update 4/20/2015 - Updated openscad code to fix the preview in customizer, thanks to wstein for the tip!  
Update 5/10/2015 - Updated source file to fix issue with starting filament hole for some configurations when using customizer.

title: SCRU-FE: Simple C++ Robot with Ultra-sonic Sensor for Education: Arduino UNO Obstacle Avoidance Maze Programming

description.text: S.C.R.U.-F.E.: Simple C++ Robot with Ultrasonic-sensor For Education https://youtu.be/-_pw6N5LGGA If you make one of these, kindly post your make and modifications/codes/videos etc. so my students can see the progress on SCRU-FE and how far this design has made it around the world! I plan on using this design to promote the need for a realistic way to teach elementary and middle school students how programming can be simple and fun without the need for expensive kits. Please share/print/code and keep the resources flowing for education! This Robot build started when my two year old daughter fell in love with an old ultrasonic robot that I built in elementary school twenty five years ago. It's missing parts and no longer works, but she has treated it with love since she was one year old. For her third birthday, I set out to make a sub $50 Robot with easily replaceable parts (see B.O.M. in instructions) that we could make together. The fact that no individual part costs more than $10 and that all parts are easily found or open source gives me the hopes that SCRU-FE will be passed down to her children with all her great memories. My three year old daughter adores this Robot. She named him Scruffy, so I made up a silly acronym that fits his silly appearance.

Bill Of Materials Printed Body
Printed Servo Arm
Printed Sensor Mount
(2) Printed Wheel Halves Arduino UNO
UNO Motor shield (I use the L298P with buzzer, Ping and servo inputs)
Two "Smart Car" Gearmotors and wheels
Two 3AA Battery holders
Switch
SG-90 9g Micro servo set
HC-SR04 Ultrasonic sensor
200mm female/female 4 pin cable
High Amperage toggle switch (15A or better still looking for a good source can skip and take a battery out to shut the power off I burnt through a few 5A switches already :()
(4) 25mm sections of wire for motors (2) F623 bearings (wheel)
(4) M3x25mm socket capscrew (motors)
(1) M3x15mm socket capscrew (neck)
(1) M3x20mm socket capscrew (wheel)
(4) M3x8mm flat head socket capscrew (batteries)
(4) M3x6mm socket capscrew (UNO)
(6) M3 washers (wheel)
(10) M3 nylon locking nuts
several small rubber bands optional: (3) 12mm long M3 coupler nuts to make internal assembly easier (replaces 6 m3 locking nuts, (4) 12mm (6mm threaded) m3 standoff nuts for the arduino board to give it a more professional look Tools Needed: 2mm allen key
2.5mm allen key
2-3mm phillips screwdriver (small $2 kobalt set works if you dont have an electrical set)
2-3mm slotted screwdriver
5.5mm wrench (optional but recomended, $4 for kobalt)
small needle nose plies
tweezers (ESD-15 if possible)
Soldering iron with smal tip and solder
small drill
1.5mm or 1/6" drill bit
3mm or 1/8" drill bit
drill bit for chosen toggle switch Building tips:
After printing the body drill out all holes with a 3mm drill bit except for the UNO mounting holes. On my prints the M3x6mm bolts self threaded in to the plastic itself. If this doesn't work, use 8mm bolts and nylon locking nuts instead. The wheels need 3 washers or 2mm spacers on either side to allow for clearance from the lock nuts that hold the battery box on. If there is not enough clearance you can use a regular M3 nuts for the battery box or add more washers between the wheel and the body. Code: the sample code included is a quick working code, however I am no master at C++ nor Arduino so please use it as an example only.

This is a the sailboat by 3D_LabteK, published Aug 11, 2013 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:131439, with an added keel extension. The boat printed perfect, best print I've made. When I put it in the pool for my kids to play, it turned over. I used the existing keel to create a add on, slip over keel with front and back bull nose covers. The keel extension was slipped over the existing keel and the bull nose covers were super glued to the extension. The extension made the boat quite stable in the pol with the kids playing. The original is a great piece of work, nice lines, balanced, and a good project. All the credit goes to 3D_LabteK for the original work.

Print the original project (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:131439). Print the keel extension pieces. Slide the keel extension over the existing keel Use glue, or other method, to secure the front and rear keel bull nose covers to the keel extension. Once secured, they will lock the keel extension on to boat. I printed at .3 10% fill and required light edge de-bur. At .2 or .25, the geometry should print more precise.

This is a test jig for, and a derivative of, the parametric escapement mechanism I posted yesterday: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7785 The intent is to power the escapement with a rubber band and see:
  • whether the pendulum regulates the unwinding of the elastic and
  • whether the escapement in turn keeps the pendulum moving despite friction
    • I suspect it will NOT work as is, but some parametric tweaks might get it going. May need to add some other weigh at the end of the pendulum, the plastic may not be enough. Also not sure if this would work printed... the escapement wheel's teeth are pretty fine at the tips. Lastly, the code is less well commented that the parent thing's. I'll fix that later, promise. :-) (EDIT: I have cleaned up the code and broken it into a library, and a test script. That is the code I will be maintaining and it can be found as its own thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7822 )

Print out the drum, the pendulum and the support.
Attach the support to a vertical surface, and slip the drum and pendulum onto their respective pegs (see jpeg for what goes where).
Attach one end of a rubber band to the side of the drum, wind it around the drum a couple times (nothing too tight, just a little potential energy for the machine) and attach the other end to the remaining peg.
Push everything as far back as it will go against the stops, making the pendulum's escapement pallets mesh with the drum's teeth, and let go. Give the pendulum a gentle nudge to get it going.
Write an angry comment here telling me it didn't work! ;-)

description.text: A simple little fairy house I made for my daughter and her two best friends. The top is removable and you can place a battery operated tea light inside.

• Print it (I used both rafts and supports)
  • Paint it
  • Light it (with a battery tea light)
  • Enjoy

comments.text: I had trouble printing this on my first 2 attempts. Close inspection revealed that the porch supports sit slightly below the bottom of main house. Without raft or supports, the house section will not begin to print until layer 3 or 4 (so stringy layer with bad adhesion as you would without proper print leveling/setup). I ended up removing 1mm from the bottom of the full model so that the main house was not left floating. The first layer then went down properly with both porch supports and main base on layer 1. Thank you for making/sharing this model. My girlfriend is excited to paint it and set it out in the garden.
comments.author: toreadored

comments.text: I noticed that when I was getting ready to slice it.  My solution was to drop it in Tinkercad and cut 1mm off the bottom.  It's unnoticeable and now it makes good contact.

title: Beaglebone Black Drilling And Mounting Plates

description.text:
This thing contains a mounting plate and a drilling guide for the “Beaglebone Black”.  
The plates are not symmetrical. The notch shall be on the power jack and ethernet cable side. The base plate is 2 mm thick. M2 5 mm or 1/4″ 4-40 screws are needed to fasten the board to the mounting plate. The mounting holes are three mm in diameter.  
The holes do not go through the lower layer to make it easier to print. You will have to drill them.

You can upload the attached .zip file to the Open Source Hardware Park (www.oshpark.com) and order your own PCB boards.

Programmable System-on-Chip, and you can make you very own copies of this thingy! Have Fun!

author: Mauronic

description.text:
Solidworks project for a Borderlands loot chest I made. Now you too can stash all your epic loot! Complete with a hinge and 100% PLA decorative locking mechanism.  
There are 4 parts: the top, the bottom, the bolt and the cap to be placed on the bolt. These are all contained in the two .thing and .x3g files  
I attached a ton of source files, but the only thing you need to do is print the .x3g files. The bottom has its own print file while the top, bolt and bolt cap are in the second file.   
The STL files are attached as well if you want to re-size/rearrange the files in the print. The SolidWorks Models are also included if you want to change the model around.  
I want to see your results if you print one! Please show me!

The files use supports and rafts, so if you want to change anything, you'll have to start from the .thing files. The .x3g files are 10% infill, standard (2 mm infill),  
Just take the two .x3g files and print them using your very own Makerbot Replicator 2!  (or another printer if it suits you)  
The hinge holes may have to be re-sized after the supports are removed. I suggest using a rounded diamond file. I re-sized the bolt cap since it was difficult to get it to fit without filing the inside down. I also flipped it upside down in the .thing file since it was printing supports inside it. I haven't printed the updated version of the bolt cap, but it can always be refitted with a file.  
Warning: The STL file for the top is at a very slight angle for some reason and I'm not sure how to fix it. If you wish to start from the STL files, just be careful to make sure the top is as flat as it can get. The print I made (see pictures) was printed at this small angle and it resulted in a small pattern of stripes, but it's not a big deal. It actually looks good.  
Send me a message if you need any help!

title: Trinity Labs 1 Aluminatus - z axis stepper thrust bearing holder.

description.text:
This is a coaxial mounted thrust bearing mount for the Z axis steppers of a Trinity Labs Aluminatus printer. I mounted it to studs that run through the deck of the printer. There are clearance pockets on the bottom for the nuts that hold the stepper in place. The coupler can be adjusted through the front and rear openings.
The design is in OpenSCAD and uses parms for most things. I've added an update that uses a true thrust bearing, in particular a 7x13x4.5 miniature thrust bearing. I added a screw on cap to retain the bearing.

comments.text: i'd like to use this on my prusa variant - which uses 8mm lead screws, just got a few questions:
comments.author: thed0ct0r

comments.text:
Hi,
I didn't remember what the lead screws were, so I took a caliper to them. The minor diameter (at the bottom of the threads, if I've got my terminology right) is a bit over 8 mm. The major diameter is about 10 mm. I replaced the original flex couplers, and turned the ends of the lead screws down to fit the new flex couplers. And I left a shoulder that matched the inner diameter of the thrust bearing. None of it was very precise, but then it didn't seem to need precision on that area, just a stable fit. Then I set the SCAD up to make a snug pocket for the thrust bearing. I just wanted an official thrust bearing (since it is a thrust load), no proper engineering reason. So, I really can't say anything useful about the choice of other bearings.
I did try an arrangement where the "shoulder" that sat on the thrust bearing was the threads of the lead screw. That seemed to have a visible wobble, which I couldn't understand, so I resized things, and turned a solid shoulder below the threads.
comments.author: thed0ct0r

comments.text:
thanks for the detailed info - though i'm not sure i understand.
you mentioned using an f7-13m thrust bearing (7mm13mm4.5mm) - so inner diameter should be 7mm. how did you fit it onto an 8mm shaft? did you machine it? or did i understand you incorrectly?
comments.author: kenaaker

comments.text:
I'll try to be a little clearer. I'm a bit distracted this morning.
I turned down the end of the lead screw so there were three reduced sections. The smallest section (at the end of the leadscrew) was a diameter that matched the flexible aluminum coupler that sits inside the pocket of the mount, and was long enough to mount securely in the flex coupler, but not so long that it put the thrust load on the stepper shaft. The next, slightly larger section, is has a diameter that is a sliding fit in the center of the thrust bearing. The third reduced section is larger than the hole in the thrust bearing, so it transfers the thrust load from the lead screw to the thrust bearing. Above that is the untouched leadscrew threads.
Looking at the lead screw you pointed to, it seems like you will have to either turn one of the ends down into something similar to what I did, or fabricate a coupler that mates to the end and provides a shoulder that can transfer the thrust.
comments.author: thed0ct0r

comments.text:
ahhh i see - so your lead screw is machine ended... probably something like they do to ball screws (i think it's called bk10/bf10 finish).
i don't think i'll machine end my screws (though i might look for compatible cheap ones with a machined end... something to think about), so do you think it'd be a good idea to use 8mm thrust bearings just above the coupler and have them press down on the coupler (it's a flex one, though i do have some rigid ones)? or should i jest get a brass nut like the ones i'm using for my z carriage now and have that press down on the thrust bearings (kinda like what you have - only created artificially)?
comments.author: kenaaker

comments.text:
Well, there are probably some Mech. Eng. guys around who would know better than me. I'm mostly software skills. But, I assumed the flex coupler is there mostly to deal with any alignment mismatch between the stepper motor shaft and the lead screw. So, putting a thrust load on top of the flex coupler would probably remove most of the"flex" capability they have. I think the phrase I've run across most commonly was that you would want your lead screws to be "minimally constrained" on all but the axis of motion (along it's length). If you try to pin it down too rigidly (on too many axes), you will wind up with binding, or periodic distortion as you change height. With two z-axis lead screws involved, it gets ugly quickly (parallelism in multiple planes,...).
The reason I made this mount was to separate the issues. The flex coupler is only responsible for getting the stepper motor motion to the lead screw. The thrust bearing and mount was supposed to transfer the weight of the x-axis mechanism directly to the base plate.
comments.author: thed0ct0r

comments.text: thanks - that makes total sense... i think i'll go for the second option then, get another nut for each of the lead screws and have that pressed down on the thrust bearing - so essentially i have a setup similar to yours (maybe even weld that nut to the screw).
comments.author: kenaaker

comments.text: I printed these for my Aluminatus and am realizing that I have no idea how the stepper motor is mounted - from your picture it appears the coupler is sitting a lot lower than mine, which makes me imagine that the stepper is possibly mounted lower (i.e. not flush against the alu top plate). Could you explain how and and what parts you used to mount the motors?
comments.author: lithiolabs

comments.text:
Hi,
The stepper motors are in the same place. I just replaced the screws that went through the top plate with studs that I made by cutting the heads off some m3x10mm screws. Then I put a nut on the stud that screwed down against the top plate to hold the stepper in place. The pockets on the bottom of the mount are there to clear the nuts that are holding the stepper motor in place.
Then, the mount goes over the studs, and is held in place with m3 washers and nuts.
Ken
comments.author: lithiolabs

title: Bolt holder for Z endstop on Printrbot Jr

description.text: A holder for the bolts that holds the Z endstop screw in place on the Printrbot Jr. The screw kept loosening and the bottom bolt rolled down, so I made this little holder ting. Seems to work just fine (although it could - should - be tighter around the wood). Also eliminates the need for a wrench when adjusting the screw. Welle417 made a tighter version - you might want to print that in stead: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:82896

I printed PLA at 30% infill, which worked... 1) Adjust the two bolts so they have a flat side parallel with the long side of the wood they are "clamping".
2) Push the printed thing over the two bolts so it's as tight as possible.
3) Readjust the z endstop screw, if needed. It isn't 100% tight around the wood, but works fine for me. If it's too loose, try pushing it farther in toward the bolt. As an alternative a little piece of paper wedged between the thing and the wood should make it stick better. I didn't need to do it, but I have a feeling each printrbot is a little different from the others...

description.text: wine glass

I made this filament spool holder adapter for the Ultibots K250 V-Slot (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:456659). I found that the spool holder that came with the printer was great for my regular sized Hatchbox spools, but I wanted to use the Octave Green filament to make some other things. This was also a test to how large the printer would print and this printer did great even on a large print. I have only had the printer put together for about a week and it has done awesome. Still working out a few different things, but its getting close to being perfect. I dimensioned this based on the full size hatchbox spool. This is a two part design since spools have different inside diameters. I tested the filament rod on the following filament spools for fitment:
Octave 1kg Spool
3D Solutech 1.1 LBS (0.5KG)
HATCHBOX 0.45kg Spool (1.0 lbs)
M3D I have a spool of Taulman t-glase Filament and the hole dimension is a lot smaller than the others mentioned above. I will have to make a different Spool Adapter Rod to Taulman filaments. The Spool Adapter Rod is 1.23 inches on the outside diameter. The base plate took just over 4 hours to print and the rod was around 2 hours, but there are some settings changes that I could have made to make for a shorter print time.

title: 5.8gHz Cloverleaf/skew-planar antenna bending tool
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Please note: I have achieved better results with this template: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:968038 although it does not comply with the rules of antenna making... Template for making perfect bends into 0.8mm copper plated MIG welding wire creating a circular polarized cloverleaf/skew-planar 5.8gHz FPV antenna. Added a 1.0mm and 1.5mm version. No idea how the antenna is going to perform with thicker wires... 2015-05-27: Added a 0.5 mm version.

Watching RCModelReviews video: https://youtu.be/yohKRzMAJAg
Using the guides and calculators from RCExplorer.se: http://rcexplorer.se/diy/2011/08/the-cloverleaf-fpv-antenna/ Produced a tool for a 5800Hz tuned cloverleaf/skew-planar antenna. The tool helps you to:
Cut a 0.8mm copper plated MIG welding wire to precisely 63mm
Then bend it 90 degrees at 13.2mm/26.5mm/13.2mm/10.1mm
Then bend a perfect loop with an angle of 115 degrees Do print the tool at 0.1mm layer height, ABS.

comments.text: Material question - you say ABS .. which has shrinkage. If i use PETG do i need to scale down?
comments.author: newbpilot

comments.text: Templates are true to dimension. Material specific settings should be handled in the slicer settings. ABS recommendation is due to higher melt temperature compared to PLA when using a soldering iron at close proximity.
comments.author: newbpilot

comments.text: Perfect! So PETG would be a good compromise. Durable and higher melting temp than PLA, less shrink that ABS (and no toxic fumes) ... I just wanted to double check. Sometimes people make models specific for a material, and I mess them up :)

author: GregFisk25

description.text: A STAR vase
ART BUILD 2
An alternative top for Amiicoin project http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:778886
Remixed from original here: https://www.myminifactory.com/object/guardians-of-the-galaxy-star-lord-s-mask-1898

Ion channels, such as potassium channels, are essential to the way our nerves work. This is a model of the potassium channel KcsA, from Streptomyces lividans. KcsA is a tetrameric protein composed of four identical subunits. "Potassium channels are designed to allow the flow of potassium ions across the membrane, but to block the flow of other ions--in particular, sodium ions."
--http://www.rcsb.org/pdb/101/motm.do?momID=38 Four copies of 1K4C-surf_fixed.stl must be printed to make the tetrameric channel. Four copies of 1K4C-K.stl must be printed to give the four ions shown in the figures. The stl files presented here are to the same scale, so the same scaling must be applied if they are rescaled. Model based on the Protein Data Bank entry 1K4C:
--http://www.pdb.org/pdb/explore/explore.do?pdbId=1k4c Model created using VMD:
http://www.ks.uiuc.edu/Research/vmd/

Successfully printed in PLA on a Makerbot Replicator2 using MakerBot Desktop beta 3.6.0.76, standard resolution with 3 shells and 15% infill. Use rafts and supports.  
Four copies of 1K4C-surf_fixed.stl are needed to make the potassium channel. They are colored dark and light blue in the pictures. Four copies of 1K4C-K.stl are needed to make the magenta spheres shown in the pictures.

title: Fan holder/mount for E3D v6 on Kossel effector

description.text:
!!! The center part is printed upside down. The fan is supposed to extend downward and the flat part is mounted up against the effector. Mounted the wrong way around the partcooling fans will blow on the hotend instead of the part. !!! 2015-06-02: Added fan duct for 5015 radial fan. It's still a work in progress.
2015-05-03: All parts updated and 40 mm versions added.
All parts are compatible. You can use a 30 mm version as center with 40 mm fans on the sides or vice versa.
Center parts now has a cutout for a nut where the side parts are attached. I found that just tapping the holes wasn't enough and the sides would come loose after a while. Using a locknut solves this.
Holes to attach 30 mm fans are 2.5 mm so you can tap them and use a M3 screw.
Holes to attach 40 mm fans are 4.5 mm as these fans are usually shipped with bigger screws. These holes also work with the rubber antivibration holders that some fans (Noctua f.ex.) are shipped with. I've tested all 30 mm fan holders and they work well.
As I'm still waiting for 2 more 40 mm fans I have yet to test the side version of the 40 mm fanholders. Right now I'm running a 40 mm center fan with 2x30mm side fans wich works well. Remixed and combined 2 parts to get a fan-holder/mount for the Kossel Mini;
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:340190
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:692384 I've printed the parts in PLA and used kapton tape where needed to protect it from heat.

SaldoT_E3D_V6_Fanholder_40mmfans-_Complete.stl contains one center and two side parts. You can also download and print the parts individually.
You fasten the middle part to the hot-end using a plastic strap. I print the parts with support everywhere, 0.8 mm shell and 50% infill.

comments.text: Not a good design.  Nearly every bolt hole is too close to the edge of the part, so when you run a screw into it, the plastic cracks.  And the zip tie slots are too fragile.  It's going in the right direction but it misses the mark by a wide margin.
comments.author: av8r1

comments.text:
I've never had a problem with it cracking. What plastic are you using when printing the part? Some are more prone to cracking than others.
The plastics I've used are folorfabb PLA/PHA and colorfabb XT which is less prone to cracking than normal PLA.
Also, if the plastic crack when inserting a screw the holes must be to small. It's a tricky situation you have to calibrate every printer individually to figure out the offset needed when designing parts. A 3mm hole could turn up as 2.5mm one one printer, 2.9 on another depending on extrusion, the orientation of the hole (vertical/horizontal) and other variables too.
Best way around it i've found is to drill the holes after the part is printed, that way you ensure it's the correct size.
Can you give me a hint how you made the 40mm duct? DSMech dosen't support blending one shape into another while extruding/pulling, other than SpaceClaim. How did you manage to get this blend?

title: Tire Valve Caps - Car / Bike Accessory

description.text:
Quick and easy print in your choice of color to accessorize your car or bike.... print a set in 'Glow-in-the-Dark' filament for a very cool effect at night.  
With a well set up 3D printer this will print the very fine thread (0.75mm pitch) so you can screw them straight on in place of existing valve caps. This is a fantastic example of the fine detail that can be printed as the thread is clearly visible (refer images).   
Refer to the instructions for printing details... this must be printed at high resolution (0.1mm) to create a clean thread.  
The file includes a MakerBot M logo so MakerBot owners in particular will appreciate this print that demonstrates the accuracy that can be achieved by looking at the thread.   
If you like this take time to check out my other designs!

Please follow these instructions carefully to ensure you get a good clean thread as it is 'very' fine but works great when printed on a well set up machine capable of accurate prints. On a Replicator 2 this prints well as follows... Raft: On
Resolution: 0.1mm / High
Support: Off
Shells: 4
Infill: 50% (...or more) If you want to change the colour of the MakerBot M as in the images Z-pause the machine at 13.0mm through the print (on a Replicator 2 with Raft on... as that is approx. 1.0mm thick)) and change colors. On machines without a Z-pause feature you will need to pause it / change filament as soon as you see the M logo starting to print.

title: Motorola Moto G + Dexcom G4 Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a remix of Round II: Nightscout Dexcom-Moto G case http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:465468.
Various lettering and graphics were removed to allow for smoother printing.
After trying various materials, such as PLA, ABS, SemiFlex, we preferred to print them in PET. The photo presents one printed in ColorFabb XT (opaque) and the other in Taulman t-glase (transparent).

Printed in ColorFabb XT and Taulman t-glase with:
0.4 mm nozzle and 0.35 mm extrusion width
0.15 layer height
40 mm/s printing speed, 15 mm/s first layer
240 Celsius nozzle temperature
40 Celsius bed temperature (covered with BuildTak)
no cooling
